INTERESTING ARRAY OF STATISTICS
Although the Registrar's Office
has not yet completed the enrollment of entering students, unofficial figures place the registration of
freshmen on Thursday at 250. Incoming transfer students have
raised the total registration of the
first day of college to 335. Approximately 250 Athletic Association
tickets have been sold. Although
the Treasurer's Office is rushing
through its various official procedures, it will not be necessary
for that office to employ any extra
help. The Registrar's Office, however, finds it necessary to add several assistants to cope with the situation created by the abnormal influx of newcomers. The first name
to appear on the list of freshmen
is Harold Abramson—while Israel
Zeligman ends the register. Drs.
Roulston, Boas, Cartledge, Cohen,
Hart, and Hubbard have been assigned as advisors to the Class of
1933. Scholarships for the School
of Economics and the College of
Arts and Sciences have already
been announced, although Engineering Scholarships have not yet
been awarded. There has been an
unprecedented number of applications both for Evening School and
for the Faculty of Philosophy,, although there has been no actual
registration.

first between the individual and
God, and later grew to be between
the individual, his fellow-man, and
God. An open period was next on
the program. During this time the
frosh took their last dip and packed
in preparation for their departure.

BY RICHARD G. HUNT
Returning to Baltimore after a vacation in New York is likely to affect even the most ardent booster with a feeling something like condescension. For instance, there is the matter of
escalators. The-boy-who-goes-to-N. Y.-with-me found escalators
and the Metropolitan Art Museum the two best things in Gotham.
As for myself, I'll go half way in this opinion; I'm not all hot
and bothered about art. A lover of escalators comes to have very
delicate feelings in regard to them. He develops a taste, and is
satisfied only with a really artistic product.
Naturally, when, upon checking-in at the Monumental City
again, I was told that here, too, there were to be escalators, my
heart dilated with a mixture of civic pride and epicurean anticipation. The expanding facilities of a local department store
(name sent upon request) were to include a set of those ingenious moving steps! With characteristic enthusiasm, I dutifully
visited the store in question and sought out the escalator (of
which, incidentally, they had forewarned the public by a working model in a window display).
A hasty but complete surveillance left me crestfallen. My
escalator sensitivity was punctured to the quick. My desire to
glory in my city was thwarted. Here, indeed, were escalators in
a destitute state. Here was a high art basely perverted.
In the first place, the setting was all out. The improvements
in the store, not yet complete, had left disorder and a bald appearance of newness. The immediate approach was marred by
an unattractive placard announcing the escalator was no- w in
use—a fact obvious to any but the blind.
Almost nauseating to the true lover of escalators was the silly, gaping crowd gathered ignobly around its lower terminus—
a crowd of haggard and ill-dressed shoppers who gazed at the
new device with all the fearful wonder of savages watching an
eclipse, only more disgusting was the presence of a coatless attendant in slipshod attire who indifferently inquired of the onlookers whether any wished to venture a ride, and who, when a
hardier soul took the chance, helped her on in the manner of a
clown at Carlin's assisting an old woman onto the Ocean Wave.

Last Friday, shortly after noon,
over one hundred freshmen and a
few upperclassmen were . jammed
into buses, and set out for the Sixth
Annual Freshman Camp, sponsored
by the Johns Hopkins University
Y. M. C. A. This Was by far the
largest number ever to enroll for
the camp, and it is safe to say that
not one felt that his time had not
been well spent.
Upon arriving at Camp Conroy,
situated on the South River, five
miles from Annapolis, the group
te lunch after a scramble for
bunks. The afternoon was devoted
to recreation such as baseball, touchfootball, boating and swimming.
At 8 o'clock the first meeting was
held. W. Purnell Hall, president of
the Student Council, welcomed the
freshmen and introduced the first
speaker of the evening, Dr. John C.
French, '99, University Librarian,
who spoke on "The Social Fraternity." Dr. French advised the men to
join fraternities if they could afford
to, but not to put'too much emphasis
upon this side of college life. He
gave examples of two students who
had made these mistakes and who
consequently ruined their college
careers. The University librarian
also advised those who did join fraternities not to let this affect their
life at Hopkins as they could make
just as many friends, and be no less
successful. In selecting a fraternity,
said Dr. French, one should size up
the men and judge the fraternity
cn the whole by the appearance of
the chapter house.
The next speaker of the evening
was Douglas C. Turnbull, Jr., '24,
former football and lacrosse star,
whose topic was "College Athletics."
The former captain of the football
team, told how much athletics meant
to him, and praised the Hopkins
coaching system. He brought to
light Hopkins' great record in Lacrosse, and stated that, if the mate
rial were on hand, an equally impressive record would be made in
football.
The last speaker on the program
was John R. Sherwood, '23, who
addressed the freshmen on "Activities." This speech was the only
humorous one of the evening, and
was well received by all. The
speaker, however, brought out one
serious point; that participation in
non-athletic activities built up personality and character.
After the meeting the frosh were
free to do as they pleased, some
going to Annapolis, others playing
cards, while a few wise ones went
to bed.
Saturday morning the same few
took an early morning dip while
the rest arose in time for breakfast
at 8.30. A general assembly was
held,at 9.30. Dr. C. E. Cunningham, 'Med. '28, spoke on the value
of books, quoting Ruskin. Purnell
Hall then explained the Honor System at Hopkins, stating that Hopkins expected every man to be a
gentleman above everything else.
Following the assembly, the freshmen were broken up into discussion
groups under the leadership of Purnell Hall, Edwin Lockard, E. A.
Schall, Clark Wisotski, and Edward
Cunningham. The topic taken up
was "Why College."
After lunch another recreation
period was held. Most of the men
went to Annapolis to see the NavyDenison football game. Two of the
freshmen made the sad mistake of
tt ying to row to the State capital
to watch the contest. They were
picked up by a speed boat in the
bay, and hence arrived in camp before dark.

Returning to Baltimore after a vacation in New York is likely to affect even the most ardent booster with a feeling something like condescension. For instance, there is the matter of
escalators. The-boy-who-goes-to-N. Y.-with-me found escalators
and the Metropolitan Art Museum the two best things in Gotham.
As for myself, I'll go half way in this opinion; I'm not all hot
and bothered about art. A lover of escalators comes to have very
delicate feelings in regard to them. He develops a taste, and is
satisfied only with a really artistic product.
Naturally, when, upon checking-in at the Monumental City
again, I was told that here, too, there were to be escalators, my
heart dilated with a mixture of civic pride and epicurean anticipation. The expanding facilities of a local department store
(name sent upon request) were to include a set of those ingenious moving steps! With characteristic enthusiasm, I dutifully
visited the store in question and sought out the escalator (of
which, incidentally, they had forewarned the public by a working model in a window display).
A hasty but complete surveillance left me crestfallen. My
escalator sensitivity was punctured to the quick. My desire to
glory in my city was thwarted. Here, indeed, were escalators in
a destitute state. Here was a high art basely perverted.
In the first place, the setting was all out. The improvements
in the store, not yet complete, had left disorder and a bald appearance of newness. The immediate approach was marred by
an unattractive placard announcing the escalator was no- w in
use—a fact obvious to any but the blind.
Almost nauseating to the true lover of escalators was the silly, gaping crowd gathered ignobly around its lower terminus—
a crowd of haggard and ill-dressed shoppers who gazed at the
new device with all the fearful wonder of savages watching an
eclipse, only more disgusting was the presence of a coatless attendant in slipshod attire who indifferently inquired of the onlookers whether any wished to venture a ride, and who, when a
hardier soul took the chance, helped her on in the manner of a
clown at Carlin's assisting an old woman onto the Ocean Wave.

FROSH CAMP TERMED
GREAT SUCCESS
New Men Pleased at Meeting
at Camp Conoy
RECORD

ATTENDANCE

Speeches and Discussions
Enlightening to
Freshmen
Last Friday, shortly after noon,
over one hundred freshmen and a
few upperclassmen were . jammed
into buses, and set out for the Sixth
Annual Freshman Camp, sponsored
by the Johns Hopkins University
Y. M. C. A. This Was by far the
largest number ever to enroll for
the camp, and it is safe to say that
not one felt that his time had not
been well spent.
Upon arriving at Camp Conroy,
situated on the South River, five
miles from Annapolis, the group
te lunch after a scramble for
bunks. The afternoon was devoted
to recreation such as baseball, touchfootball, boating and swimming.
At 8 o'clock the first meeting was
held. W. Purnell Hall, president of
the Student Council, welcomed the
freshmen and introduced the first
speaker of the evening, Dr. John C.
French, '99, University Librarian,
who spoke on "The Social Fraternity." Dr. French advised the men to
join fraternities if they could afford
to, but not to put'too much emphasis
upon this side of college life. He
gave examples of two students who
had made these mistakes and who
consequently ruined their college
careers. The University librarian
also advised those who did join fraternities not to let this affect their
life at Hopkins as they could make
just as many friends, and be no less
successful. In selecting a fraternity,
said Dr. French, one should size up
the men and judge the fraternity
cn the whole by the appearance of
the chapter house.
The next speaker of the evening
was Douglas C. Turnbull, Jr., '24,
former football and lacrosse star,
whose topic was "College Athletics."
The former captain of the football
team, told how much athletics meant
to him, and praised the Hopkins
coaching system. He brought to
light Hopkins' great record in Lacrosse, and stated that, if the mate
rial were on hand, an equally impressive record would be made in
football.
The last speaker on the program
was John R. Sherwood, '23, who
addressed the freshmen on "Activities." This speech was the only
humorous one of the evening, and
was well received by all. The
speaker, however, brought out one
serious point; that participation in
non-athletic activities built up personality and character.
After the meeting the frosh were
free to do as they pleased, some
going to Annapolis, others playing
cards, while a few wise ones went
to bed.
Saturday morning the same few
took an early morning dip while
the rest arose in time for breakfast
at 8.30. A general assembly was
held,at 9.30. Dr. C. E. Cunningham, 'Med. '28, spoke on the value
of books, quoting Ruskin. Purnell
Hall then explained the Honor System at Hopkins, stating that Hopkins expected every man to be a
gentleman above everything else.
Following the assembly, the freshmen were broken up into discussion
groups under the leadership of Purnell Hall, Edwin Lockard, E. A.
Schall, Clark Wisotski, and Edward
Cunningham. The topic taken up
was "Why College."
After lunch another recreation
period was held. Most of the men
went to Annapolis to see the NavyDenison football game. Two of the
freshmen made the sad mistake of
tt ying to row to the State capital
to watch the contest. They were
picked up by a speed boat in the
bay, and hence arrived in camp before dark.
